Back in my wasted youth I was involved with farming, and some of the old mechanical parts were pretty weird. For instance, the various ways of driving the cutter-knife on a combine harvester. The "wobble-box" wasn't obvious, and produced a reciprocating motion parallel to the input drive-shaft axis. Unfortunately, Massey-Ferguson build a wider header that overloaded the drive in heavier European crops.

And then somebody posted about a new engine design that was canted, like the way the SSMEs were mounter in the Shuttle. Instead of the zero-gimbal thrust axis being aligned with the fuselage, it was slightly offset, because of the weight of the external tank. And then that mixed experience prompted an idea. Can something be made for KSP?

The short answer is "Yes". It is fairly simple, but is it worth it?

What you have are two identical components, a sort of special washer, a short cylinder. One end is perpendicular to the axis, the other is canted, perhaps by five degrees. If you want a five-degree shift in the thrust axis, that's all you need.

But it can all be a little more subtle than that. First, the two ends are both circles. That takes a little care with the design. And the centres are both on the axis. And you use two of them, sloped-end to sloped end. If the slopes are at 180Ã‚Â° to each other, there no effect. If they're lined up, it goes to 10Ã‚Â° cant. By varying the relative rotation, you vary the amount of cant. And rotating the two parts together varies the direction.

Getting the same cant on two different assemblies could be tricky. Maybe there need to be some indexing marks on the texture.

Anyone want to have a go? Perhaps the big advantage is that this wouldn't need a plug-in. But I would wonder if I could afford the increased parts-count.
Uh.. are you asking for angled fuel tanks? If not, a picture of what you want would really help people understand what you're talking about.
